abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Petroleum Exploration
            and Development Project for the Ivory Coast was
            unsuccessful. The project failed to achieve many of its
            objectives, institutional development was negligible,
            sustainability is uncertain, and the performance of both the
            Bank and Borrower was satisfactory. Several lessons can be
            learned from this project. First, the success of the Bank in
            maintaining close confidentiality regarding Phillips'
            petroleum operations during the whole lifespan of the
            project can be used as an example for any private company
            involved in a Bank project and sensitive to confidentiality
            issues. Second, any government considering taking a working
            interest in an oilfield development should be advised to: a)
            have the most probable OROIP in the field appraised by two
            different highly-qualified specialists; and b) have a
            precise clause included in the production contract regarding
            the field development process. Third, PETROCI's
            foregone income resulting from its 10 percent interest in
            the ESPIOR field evidences the risk run by a government
            taking a working interest in a yet unproven field. Finally,
            within the envisaged Gas Project, it is recommended that
            further technical assistance to PETROCI be included.
